title: Understanding Hydration
content: Hydration involves how water is distributed in the body and the important concept of tonicity. The difference between dehydration and volume depletion and their respective health consequences and implications are crucial. Different conditions affect our daily water needs, as well as the signs of dehydration and how it can affect performance. There are various ways in which we can rehydrate and when it makes sense to add electrolytes, glucose—or a combination of both—to rehydration fluids. There are numerous sports drinks on the market and some stand out from the rest. Key takeaways related to hydration are important.

title: Water Distribution in the Body
content: Water inside the cell is called Intracellular fluid (ICF): accounts for about two-thirds of water in the body [67%]. Water outside the cell is called Extracellular fluid (ECF): about one third of the body’s water [33%]. About 25% of ECF is in blood/vasculature, which is therefore only about 8% of all water in the body — this is the plasma. About 60% of the ECF is Interstitial fluid which is therefore only about 20% of all water in the body. The remainder of ECF is transcellular fluid (includes digestive tract fluid, cerebrospinal fluid, and other fluid filling epithelium-lined spaces) [roughly 5% of all water in body].

title: Tonicity and Its Types
content: Tonicity is essentially a measure of how the concentration of one solution compares to the concentration of another solution. The way we think about this in human physiology is all relative to the concentration of a cell, because the cell is the dominant source of water. There are three types of tonicity: Isotonic – This would be if you put those red blood cells into a solution that has the same tonicity as them. Hypertonic – if you put the red blood cells into a very concentrate solution we would call that hypertonic. Hypotonic - if you put the red blood cells into a dilute solution we would call that hypotonic.

title: Dehydration and Volume Depletion
content: Dehydration and volume depletion are two different conditions with their respective health consequences and implications. Dehydration is the loss of water from the body, while volume depletion refers to the loss of both water and salts from the body. Both conditions can lead to serious health issues if not addressed promptly.

title: Rehydration Methods
content: There are various ways in which we can rehydrate. This can be done through the intake of fluids, preferably water or rehydration solutions. In some cases, it makes sense to add electrolytes, glucose—or a combination of both—to rehydration fluids. This is especially important during physical activities where these elements are lost through sweat.

title: Sports Drinks and Hydration
content: There are numerous sports drinks on the market, some of which stand out from the rest. These drinks often contain electrolytes and glucose, which can aid in rehydration and replenishing the body's energy stores. However, it's important to note that not all sports drinks are created equal, and some may contain high levels of sugar or other additives.

title: Understanding Hypertonic and Hypotonic Solutions
content: In a hypertonic solution, the cells would shrivel up as they lose water into the more concentrated surrounding solution. If you put water into a hypotonic solution, there’s going to be an influx of water into the cells and they’ll eventually swell until they rupture. The tonicity of pure water is essentially zero. When we give IV fluids, we have to give them relatively close to isotonic solutions. They can be a little hypertonic in the case of head injuries, as you’re trying to reduce the swelling in their brains, or as you’re trying to suck fluid out. You can also give slightly hypotonic solutions if a person already has too many electrolytes on board.

title: Determining the Tonicity of Blood
content: The lion’s share of tonicity within the human physiologic system is contributed by sodium and it’s counterion chloride. Sodium chloride (salt) accounts for about 85% of the tonicity of the extracellular space. The other things that contribute to it are glucose and blood urea nitrogen. The general formula to estimate a person’s plasma osmolality is: Plasma osmolality = 2[Na+] + (Glucose / 18) + (Blood Urea Nitrogen / 2.8).

title: Defining Dehydration and Volume Depletion
content: Dehydration is a loss of water only, but without an appreciable loss of sodium or any other osmole. By definition, if you are dehydrated, your tonicity should be going up. Volume depletion, which more accurately would be called hypovolemia, is a reduction of extracellular volume, but it also requires a loss of sodium as well. Sodium is the predominant determinant of our tonicity or the osmolality.

title: Health Consequences of Dehydration and Volume Depletion
content: In the hospital, monitoring hydration status and volume status is a huge priority. The kidney is one of the most sensitive organs to the volume in your body. When a patient’s urine output goes down, that’s usually a very early sign that something is not right with their circulating volume. You can see kidney injury, hypoxic injury, cognitive impairment, dizziness, headaches, lightheadedness as a result of dehydration and volume depletion.

title: How We Lose Water
content: The most common way that water leaves our system is through urine. We also lose it through our skin with sweat and through the respiratory surface. This becomes really important under two conditions when you’re very active and when the temperature and humidity are extreme. Other things that exacerbate hydration status are natural diuretics like caffeine and alcohol.

title: Daily Water Requirements
content: Most adults who are relatively sedentary require two to three liters of water per day. Most of that comes from liquids, but some of that comes from food. The important thing is you’re able to titrate that to both your activity level and your environment, the ambient temperature, the humidity, etc.

title: Water and Salt Loss During Sweating
content: Sweat is hypotonic. The sodium concentration of sweat is going to be somewhere between 20 and 60 milliequivalents per liter, or millimole per liter. That variability is going to be a function of hydration status. The more hydrated you are, the lower that concentration is going to be.

title: Signs of Dehydration During Exercise
content: The heart works like a pump. It has a pretty important characteristic, which is called preload. Every time the heart is about to beat, it starts in a pumped position and then it contracts, and that’s called the ejection fraction. The heart is a muscle that likes to have some stretch in it before it contracts so it’s stronger when it has preload in it.

title: Effects of Dehydration on Athletic Performance
content: Dehydration can significantly impact athletic performance. One of the first signs of dehydration in an individual trying to perform is an increased heart rate. Dehydration affects cardiac output, decreasing contractility because of preload and driving up heart rate. The first sign in an athlete who’s dehydrated is a higher heart rate than they should have. Dehydration can also impact glucose and electrolyte levels. If you are dehydrated, you are likely not replacing glucose, which is the most important thing we need to be replenishing while exercising along with electrolytes. Dehydration can also lead to a significant hit in performance. By the time a person is losing 4% or 5% of their body mass in water loss, they’re experiencing loss of alertness, cramping, extreme fatigue, dizziness, and possibly hyperthermia.

title: Overhydration and its Effects
content: Overhydration is possible, but it mostly happens in a hospital setting when too much hypotonic IV fluid is given, which can eventually reduce the concentration of sodium significantly, leading to a condition called hyponatremia. Symptoms of hyponatremia can range from dizziness, bloating, fatigue, nausea to confusion, vomiting, shortness of breath, seizures, and even coma. Overhydration can happen during exercise when people are exercising in high heat, requiring them to drink a lot over a long period of time. This can lead to a constant dilution of their plasma, which can be dangerous.

title: Importance of Electrolytes in Rehydration Fluids
content: Electrolytes are crucial in rehydration fluids. Sodium is the most obvious component because it’s the thing that we are dominantly losing. Most of our intracellular tonicity is determined by the extracellular concentration, the plasma concentration of sodium. Other electrolytes that are commonly added to mixes include magnesium and potassium. However, potassium should be given with caution as getting it wrong can be deadly.

title: Role of Glucose in Rehydration Fluids
content: The need for glucose in rehydration fluids depends on the duration of your activity. For relatively short duration activity, you really don’t need glucose as you should have sufficient muscle glycogen and liver glycogen to meet all your needs. However, for longer duration activities, glucose becomes necessary. Glucose in rehydration fluids can also facilitate the absorption of electrolytes faster. A glucose containing solution of about 5% to 6% is the sweet spot for rehydration fluids.

title: Glucose Improves Absorption of Sodium
content: One benefit of glucose is that it makes it easier to absorb sodium. This is why adding glucose at the right amount to an electrolyte drink can speed up the absorption.

title: Transmembrane Cotransport of Sodium and Glucose
content: Glucose and sodium in the lumen are technically in the body, but they haven’t been absorbed into the vascular system yet. The concentration of glucose there is low relative to the concentration of glucose in the body. To get glucose in, it has to move up its gradient. Conversely, sodium concentration is higher there than it is on the inside of the cell. Sodium concentration, intracellularly, is very low, just as potassium concentration outside of the cell is very low. There is a synergy energetically by bringing glucose in and coupling it to bringing sodium in. When you move sodium and glucose across their gradients, which are opposite, one is up, one is down, you facilitate that better. Two sodium ions moving with one glucose molecule is a very efficient way to do this. That movement of sodium into the cells also draws water into the epithelial cell, which then moves water into the extracellular fluid as sodium is then pumped into the extracellular system via that sodium, potassium pump at the bottom of the picture, what we call the basolateral cell.

title: Sports Drinks Composition
content: Sports drinks should really be hypotonic to maybe almost isotonic. They should probably contain both glucose and sodium if you’re trying to maximize the amount of water that’s going to be absorbed and also, of course, provide some amount of glucose. Soft drinks and things like that are obviously very hypertonic. And paradoxically, they can exacerbate dehydration in the long run, because they get this gradient wrong. So, fluid moves in the wrong direction. It triggers what’s called water secretion. Water going from the inside of the body back into the lumen.

title: Types of Carbohydrates in Drinks
content: The type of carbohydrates in drinks can actually impact performance. There were days when people thought it should just be pure glucose. Alternatively, there were sports drinks that were made with pure fructose. You could have isocaloric mixture of all fructose versus all glucose, and they would behave very differently. The fructose one would be a lot sweeter. But the fructose one would actually result in a lot of gastric distress, even at isocaloric levels relative to glucose. There was just more difficulties absorbing it and emptying from the gut. Then you also look at other types of glucose that are complex such as maltodextrin. Maltodextrin, common in sports drinks, is just a huge oligomer made up of glucose. It’s effectively like glycogen and it’s easier to get more glucose in through maltodextrin because it does exit the stomach a little bit slower.

title: Optimal Ratio of Carbohydrate to Sodium
content: When you’re sweating, you’re losing 20-60 millimole per liter, which is about a third to a fifth of what’s going on in your blood. So you do need to be replacing sodium. Ideally, you want a hypotonic solution given that you are losing a hypotonic solution. We’ve just established that mixing glucose with sodium increases the absorption of both along with water. We’ve established that you need sodium because you’re losing it. Obviously, we need glucose for long enough activity amount, but how much? An interesting study looked at this and concluded that at a ratio of about 2.0 you see the maximal water absorption. But a ratio of 2.0 can be different things. It could be glucose concentration of 200, sodium concentration of 100. What turns out to be the right number? It turns out that about 110 to 120 millimole of glucose and about 60 millimole of sodium gets us there.

title: Pros and Cons of Sports Drinks
content: People tend to gravitate towards ones that taste best. Gatorade/Powerade type drinks are hypertonic – the fact that they have close to 400 milliosmoles just tells me that this is not a winning solution. It tastes good. You’ll drink a bunch of it, but it’s kind of in the long run, more dehydrating. And for many people, it can upset their gut. In the end though, that much carbohydrate is just not necessary. Better options include LMNT, Nuun, Liquid IV. It’s probably the case that Liquid IV results in the greatest amount of water absorption because it’s pairing and coupling glucose to sodium. It’s also providing you with glucose—so if you’re doing something where you need the glucose, then that’s probably the one to turn to. Conversely, if you just need hydration, LMNT and Nuun probably offer you something better in that you’re still getting the electrolytes, but you’re not necessarily getting the excess glucose that you might not need.

title: Hydration from Food
content: How much water do we get throughout a day through eating food? It depends on the food. The more fat you’re eating, the less water you’re getting. The more anhydrous the food, the less water you’re getting. General rule of thumb, you probably get 20% to 30% of your water intake through food though.

title: Drinking Electrolytes Without Exercise
content: If someone doesn’t exercise on a given day, are there repercussions to drinking fluids with added electrolytes? Is it beneficial because it’s helping with the electrolyte hydration for the next day? Fluids with electrolytes only (e.g., no glucose) are much better than something with glucose (e.g., Liquid IV).

title: Key Takeaways Related to Hydration
content: Always think about the difference between what’s hypotonic, what’s isotonic, what’s hypertonic. Sodium dictates your hydration status and where your body water is distributed. Most of the time when people talk about dehydration, what they’re really talking about is volume depletion which involves not just a loss of water, but a loss of sodium. A good rehydration strategy requires some replacement of water salt in the proportions that they’ve been lost. Carbohydrates are an important component of rehydration for long, challenging endurance sports drinks because you’re losing glycogen, and because it also facilitates water absorption through that co-transporter of glucose and sodium. Find your strategy and tinker with this stuff, you’ve got to figure out how it works for you.

title: Hydration Mixes
content: For the Liquid IV, LMNT, Nuun, and other mixes… mixing them according to the directions that they provide is smart as they’ve generally done a lot of work on this and they sort of know the optimal plays. If using glucose in your fluids, look for the 2:1 glucose to sodium concentration.

title: Purpose of Hydration
content: Anytime I’m not drinking [plain] water, there’s really a purpose that I’m trying to serve in terms of glucose and/or electrolyte replacement and improving hydration status and water absorption.
